Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Cultural Models of Nature across Cultures: Space, Causality, and Primary Food Producers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This cross-cultural research investigates cultural models (CMs) of nature held by populations across several cultures and five continents ranging from long-time primary food producers, e.g., farmers, fishermen, herders (and also hunters and gatherers) to those who recently shifted to become primary food consumers due to globalization forces. CMs of nature, typically held out of one's or a community's awareness, affect environmental actions in ways not necessarily predicted by more traditional ecological models. The project comprises fifteen scholars and six graduate students who are experts in a particular cultural area. Linguistic and experimental data will be collected and analyzed by a common protocol that combines qualitative and quantitative approaches. Methodology and ethnography play paramount roles.

Researchers expect to discover a variety of CMs of nature that characterize each community investigated. These CMs represent specific organizations of the constitutive categories underlying the concept of nature, that is, humans, animals, plants, weather, physical environment, and the supernatural. They also expect causal relationships to be one of the major forces (in addition to spatial relationships) weaving together these categories. Similarly, while attributed to different elements and in a different potency, intentionality will be universally present.

The results, because of the focus on primary food producers, will provide insights on how this kind of population typically constructs a CM of nature. In addition, one can explore the possibility that conceptions of space are central to the construction of CMs (in this case, of nature), thus, provide supporting evidence for an architecture of the mind that includes a major role for the spatial domain in the forming of other domains of knowledge. Finally and more importantly, the findings are intended to supply policy makers, i.e., major actors in finding solutions to climate change induced problems, with information on indigenous CMs of nature that will assist them in their decision-making.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We investigated cultural models of Nature held by food-producing groups who directly experience the effects of climate change (e.g., farmers, fishermen, herders, and hunter-gatherers). Studies were conducted in 14 communities on 6 continents (see Image). We define cultural models as systematically organized mental representations that are shared by members of a culture (Bennardo and de Munck, 2014), are socially transmitted, and carry coercive force. These representations function to make sense of and interpret sensory input and also to produce and shape behaviors.

We assign distinct meanings to capitalized ‘Nature’ versus the lower case ‘nature.’ Lower case nature is typically intended to mean a specific part and type of the environment (e.g., woods, trees, rivers, etc.) or some biologically given aspect of existence (i.e., instinct, essence), while Nature may include everything that exists. That is, a cultural model of Nature is the way in which a community understand how the world works—establishing relationship among its major components such as humans, plants, animals, physical environment, weather, and supernatural.

During this research, the investigators went to their respective cultural sites, i.e., communities, to collect data for each to construct a preliminary hypothesis about cultural models of Nature. The methodological tools employed included participant observation, nature walks, open interviews, semi-structured interviews, and free listing tasks (about major components of Nature). The data analysis stage involved gist, key word, semantic role, metaphor, reasoning, and causality analyses (for the linguistic data) as well as a number of frequency analyses. All the researchers used the same strategies for data collection, including the content of the semi-structured interviews. The free listing prompts were adjusted in response to the linguistic and cultural categories present in the communities. The researchers all used the same strategies for data collection and analysis.

Results have been presented at organized panels and individual presentations: AAA 2014, 2015, 2016? SASci 2015, 2016, 2017; ANUAC (Italy) November 2015; and ASA (UK) July 2016. In addition, results were presented in invited presentations at the Universities of Verona, Padua, and Venice in Italy, and at Sun-Yat-Sen University, Guanzhou in China. The research team has 9 related articles published in a special issue of the peer-reviewed journal World Cultures. Other publications include 11 papers from the Proceedings of the team’s three-day workshop in Verona (ESE Institute, NIU, 2016), and a contract with Routledge (2018) to publish an edited book in which the results of the first phase of the project will appear as 11 separate chapters. Bennardo has in press chapters with Oxford University Press and Wiley, and published an article "The Fundamental Role of Causal Models in Cultural Models of Nature" in Frontiers in Psychology.

The research results enrich the literature about cultural models. The focus on one type of population—primary food producers in communities affected by climate change—provides insights about how livelihood as a cultural lens may inform constructions of and uses of particular models. We used a cultural model approach that regards culture as comprising and constituting the content and organization of knowledge in individual minds. This knowledge is unevenly distributed across members of a community (cultural epidemiology). This approach called for a unique methodology.

The results contribute to translating indigenous knowledge into understanding how people-environment relations can be used for effective policy-making. Cultural models of Nature are a salient part of local knowledge and fundamental to anticipating how people are likely to respond to significant, rapid changes in their physical environment because these models contribute to the generation of those responses. Access to these models allows researchers to better understand human behavior in communities facing climate change and assist authorities in determining effective policies that promote behaviors adaptive to changing local and global conditions. Without considering local knowledge, resistance is likely to be the outcome to proposed policy changes.

This research has obtained a broad impact through involving several PIs and collaborators from groups that are underrepresented in science; presenting results at national and international conferences in Europe (Italy, UK, Lithuania) and China; training of three PhD and three MA students in anthropology in facets of the research on cultural models; and important connections in many of the field sites with local institutions interested in climate and environmental change. For example, the Director of the Department of City Planning and Energy of the Autonomous Province of Bolzano, Italy asked Bennardo to submit a proposal for research in the Alpine area of the Province using this project as a model to help implement their climate change policies.
